DOC.brief_summary: The LLLT has an anti-inflammatory, analgesic effect and accelerates the healing of ulcerated lesions. There are little data in the literature showing its efficacy in prevention of mucositis in cohorts of patients with hematopoietic stem cells transplantation. The main objective of this study is to assess the efficacy of a prophylactic low level laser therapy on the severity of oral mucositis during HSCT.
DOC.brief_title: Efficacy of Prophylactic Low Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for Decreasing Severity of Oral Mucositis During Hematopoietic Stem Cell (HSC) Transplantation
DOC.detailed_description: The main end point for efficacy is the reduction of severe mucositis (grade 3 or more). The secondary efficacy endpoints are the reduction of mucositis, whatever the grade, the reduction of time with mucositis, the time to onset of mucositis symptoms, the reduction of pain intensity and evaluation of quality of life.The secondary endpoints for safety are severe adverse events and potential toxicity. Patients will be allocated at inclusion with a 1/1 ratio either to laser-on or laser-off groups. In the laser group, patients will undergo laser therapy, which will consist of irradiation of the whole oral cavity during 2 minutes with 250mW power. In the laser-off group, laser therapy will be carried out with equipment off during the same time. Protective eye shields will be used to avoid detrimental effects on eyes and to keep the subjects blind.
DOC.criteria: Patient with hematologic malignancies (myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia). Patient undergoing autologous or allogeneic HSC transplantation with myeloablative conditioning Patient affiliated to a social security Signed inform consent Patient undergoing HSCT with reduced intensity conditioning Slavin (FB2) or Seattle (F2 Gy TBI) Protected Maggiore Pregnant woman Patient with pacemaker Epileptic Patient
